nodes.text: The Naive Bayes classifier is an effective and reliable method for identifying and filtering spam emails on a combined email dataset
Spam email detection is an important problem because unsolicited emails are pervasive and pose security and usability risks
Naive Bayes operates by applying Bayes theorem with the conditional independence assumption and uses word occurrence features to compute class probabilities
This study applied a Naive Bayes pipeline including text cleaning, tokenization, Bag of Words feature extraction, Laplace smoothing, and posterior comparison to classify emails
The paper evaluates the classifier on a combined dataset from the 2007 TREC Public Spam Corpus and the Enron-Spam Dataset
Conditional independence assumption allows efficient processing of large text datasets despite ignoring term interactions
Laplace smoothing is applied to likelihood estimates to avoid zero probabilities for unseen words
Preprocessing steps performed: remove noninformative characters and stop words, lowercase conversion, tokenize text into words, and extract Bag of Words frequency vectors
Prediction is made by computing class priors and word likelihoods, multiplying likelihoods across words to get P(x|class), then selecting class with highest posterior probability
Combined dataset contains 83,446 emails: 43,910 spam (52.62%) and 39,538 ham (47.38%)
Dataset was randomly split 80% training (66,756 emails) and 20% testing (16,690 emails) preserving class proportions
Data split resulted in training counts: 35,128 spam and 31,630 ham; test counts: 8,782 spam and 7,908 ham
Model selection used 5-fold cross-validation yielding fold accuracies 0.9733, 0.9766, 0.9762, 0.9759, 0.9755 and mean 0.9751
The best model (from fold 2) trained on full training data achieved 97.82% accuracy on the test set
Confusion matrix test outcomes: ham test accuracy 98.64% (7800/7908 correct), spam test accuracy 97.08% (8526/8782 correct); overall metrics precision, recall, and F1 approximately 0.98
High and consistent precision, recall, and F1 across both classes indicate the Naive Bayes model effectively distinguishes spam and ham on this dataset
Conclusion: Naive Bayes is a powerful, stable tool for spam detection on the evaluated datasets; future work could explore hybrid models and deeper contextual or semantic analysis
